lessons.title: Registers & MOV
lessons.theory: Registers are the CPU's fastest storage locations. EduASM has 8 general-purpose registers (R0-R7) plus special registers (SP, BP, IP). The MOV instruction copies values between registers or loads immediate values using the # prefix.

snippets.label: Hello Registers
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #42
MOV R1, #100
MOV R2, R0
HALT

snippets.label: Register Chain
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
MOV R1, R0
MOV R2, R1
MOV R3, R2
HALT

quiz.q: What does MOV R0, #25 do?
After MOV R1, R0, what happens to R0?

lessons.title: LOAD/STORE & Addressing
lessons.theory: Memory operations transfer data between registers and RAM. LOAD copies from memory to register, STORE copies from register to memory. Use square brackets [addr] for memory addresses, and support offsets like [R1+4].

snippets.label: Basic Memory
snippets.source:
.DATA
value: .WORD 123
.TEXT
LOAD R0, [value]
STORE [value], R0
HALT

snippets.label: Pointer Arithmetic
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 10, 20, 30
.TEXT
MOV R1, array
LOAD R0, [R1]
LOAD R2, [R1+4]
HALT

quiz.q: What does LOAD R0, [100] do?
options: Loads the value at memory address 100 into R0

quiz.q: How do you access the second element of an array starting at R1?

lessons.title: ADD/SUB & Flags
lessons.theory: Arithmetic instructions modify registers and set CPU flags. ADD/SUB update Zero Flag (ZF), Negative Flag (NF), Carry Flag (CF), and Overflow Flag (OF). These flags are crucial for conditional operations and loops.

snippets.label: Basic Math
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
MOV R1, #5
ADD R0, R1
SUB R0, #3
HALT

snippets.label: Flag Demo
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #5
SUB R0, #5
; ZF should be set
MOV R1, #1
SUB R1, #2
; NF should be set
HALT

quiz.q: After SUB R0, R0, which flag is set?
What happens to R0 after ADD R0, R1?

lessons.title: CMP & Branches
lessons.theory: CMP compares two values by performing subtraction without storing the result, only setting flags. Conditional jumps (JZ, JNZ, JL, JG, etc.) check these flags to change program flow. Unconditional JMP always jumps.

snippets.label: Simple Branch
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
CMP R0, #5
JG greater
MOV R1, #0
JMP end
greater:
MOV R1, #1
end:
HALT

snippets.label: Equal Check
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #42
MOV R1, #42
CMP R0, R1
JZ equal
MOV R2, #0
JMP done
equal:
MOV R2, #1
done:
HALT

quiz.q: What does CMP R0, R1 do to R0 and R1?
When does JZ jump?

lessons.title: Loops & Counters
goals: Combine CMP with jumps for iteration
lessons.theory: Loops repeat code sections using counters and conditional jumps. Initialize a counter, execute loop body, decrement counter, then check if done. The DEC instruction decrements and sets flags, making loop conditions simple.

snippets.label: Count to 5
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #0
MOV R1, #5
loop:
INC R0
DEC R1
JNZ loop
HALT

snippets.label: Sum 1 to N
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #0
MOV R1, #5
loop:
ADD R0, R1
DEC R1
JNZ loop
HALT

quiz.q: What does DEC R0 do besides decrementing?
In a counting loop, when do you typically check the counter?
options: In the middle of loop body

lessons.title: Stack PUSH/POP
lessons.theory: The stack is a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) data structure. PUSH adds values to the top, POP removes them. The Stack Pointer (SP) tracks the current top. Stack grows downward in memory, so PUSH decrements SP, POP increments it.

snippets.label: Basic Stack
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
MOV R1, #20
PUSH R0
PUSH R1
POP R2
POP R3
HALT

snippets.label: Save & Restore
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #42
PUSH R0
MOV R0, #99
; R0 changed
POP R0
; R0 restored
HALT

quiz.q: After PUSH R0, what happens to SP?
If you PUSH R0 then PUSH R1, what does POP return first?

lessons.title: CALL/RET Functions
lessons.theory: Functions are reusable code blocks. CALL pushes the return address and jumps to the function. RET pops the return address and jumps back. Use registers or stack for parameters. BP (Base Pointer) helps manage stack frames.

snippets.label: Simple Function
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #5
CALL double
HALT

double:
ADD R0, R0
RET

snippets.label: Stack Frame
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #3
CALL square
HALT

square:
PUSH BP
MOV BP, SP
MUL R0, R0
MOV SP, BP
POP BP
RET

quiz.q: What does CALL instruction do first?
What should a function do before RET?

lessons.title: String Operations
lessons.theory: Strings are sequences of bytes ending with null (0). Use byte operations to read characters. Increment pointer to move through string. Common operations: length calculation, copying, comparison.

snippets.label: String Length
snippets.source:
.DATA
str: .STRING "Hello"
.TEXT
MOV R0, str
MOV R1, #0
loop:
LOADB R2, [R0]
CMP R2, #0
JZ done
INC R1
INC R0
JMP loop
done:
HALT

snippets.label: Character Check
snippets.source:
.DATA
str: .STRING "ABC"
.TEXT
MOV R0, str
LOADB R1, [R0]
; R1 = 'A' = 65
HALT

quiz.q: How do you know when a string ends?
What instruction reads a single byte?

lessons.title: Array Processing
lessons.theory: Arrays store multiple values of the same type consecutively in memory. Calculate element address: base + (index * element_size). For 32-bit integers, each element is 4 bytes apart. Use loops to process all elements.

snippets.label: Array Sum
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
count: .WORD 5
.TEXT
MOV R0, #0
MOV R1, array
LOAD R2, [count]
loop:
CMP R2, #0
JZ done
LOAD R3, [R1]
ADD R0, R3
ADD R1, #4
DEC R2
JMP loop
done:
HALT

snippets.label: Find Max
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 3, 7, 2, 9, 1
.TEXT
MOV R0, array
LOAD R1, [R0]
MOV R2, #4
loop:
ADD R0, #4
LOAD R3, [R0]
CMP R3, R1
JLE skip
MOV R1, R3
skip:
DEC R2
JNZ loop
HALT

quiz.q: If an array starts at address 1000, where is the 3rd element (index 2)?
Why add 4 to move to next array element?

lessons.title: System Calls
lessons.theory: System calls interface with the operating system. SYS #1 prints R0 as integer, SYS #2 prints string at address in R1, SYS #3 exits with code in R0. These allow programs to produce output and terminate cleanly.

snippets.label: Print Number
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #42
SYS #1
MOV R0, #0
SYS #3
HALT

snippets.label: Print String
snippets.source:
.DATA
msg: .STRING "Hello World"
.TEXT
MOV R1, msg
SYS #2
MOV R0, #0
SYS #3
HALT

quiz.q: What does SYS #1 do?
Which register holds the string address for SYS #2?

lessons.title: Addressing Modes Deep Dive
lessons.theory: Addressing modes determine how operands are accessed. Immediate (#value) uses constants, register uses register contents, direct [addr] accesses memory, indirect [reg] uses register as pointer, and indexed [base+offset] combines base address with offset for array access.

snippets.label: All Modes Demo
snippets.source:
.DATA
value: .WORD 42
array: .WORD 10, 20, 30
.TEXT
MOV R0, #100
; Immediate
MOV R1, R0
; Register
LOAD R2, [value]
; Direct
MOV R3, value
LOAD R4, [R3]
; Indirect
LOAD R5, [array+4]
; Indexed
HALT

snippets.label: Array Indexing
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
.TEXT
MOV R0, array
MOV R1, #0
loop:
LOAD R2, [R0+R1]
ADD R1, #4
CMP R1, #20
JL loop
HALT

quiz.q: What does [R1+8] represent?
Which addressing mode is fastest?

lessons.title: Flags & Conditional Branches
lessons.theory: CPU flags indicate operation results: Zero Flag (ZF) set when result is 0, Negative Flag (NF) for negative results, Carry Flag (CF) for unsigned overflow, Overflow Flag (OF) for signed overflow. Conditional jumps test these flags: JZ/JE (zero), JNZ/JNE (not zero), JL/JB (less), JG/JA (greater).

snippets.label: Flag Truth Table
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #5
CMP R0, #5
; ZF=1, NF=0, CF=0
MOV R1, #3
CMP R1, #5
; ZF=0, NF=1, CF=1
MOV R2, #7
CMP R2, #5
; ZF=0, NF=0, CF=0
HALT

snippets.label: Conditional Logic
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
MOV R1, #0
CMP R0, #5
JLE skip1
MOV R1, #1
skip1:
CMP R0, #15
JGE skip2
MOV R1, #2
skip2:
HALT

quiz.q: After CMP R0, R1, when is Zero Flag set?
Which jump checks Carry Flag?

lessons.title: Stack Frames (SP/BP)
lessons.theory: Stack frames organize function data. SP (Stack Pointer) tracks stack top, BP (Base Pointer) marks frame start. Standard frame: PUSH BP, MOV BP,SP (setup), local variables at [BP-offset], parameters at [BP+offset], restore with MOV SP,BP; POP BP before RET.

snippets.label: Function with Frame
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
MOV R1, #5
PUSH R1
PUSH R0
CALL add_func
ADD SP, #8
HALT

add_func:
PUSH BP
MOV BP, SP
LOAD R0, [BP+8]
LOAD R1, [BP+12]
ADD R0, R1
MOV SP, BP
POP BP
RET

snippets.label: Local Variables
snippets.source:
CALL func_with_locals
HALT

func_with_locals:
PUSH BP
MOV BP, SP
SUB SP, #8
; Local space
MOV R0, #42
STORE [BP-4], R0
MOV R1, #99
STORE [BP-8], R1
LOAD R2, [BP-4]
MOV SP, BP
POP BP
RET

quiz.q: What does PUSH BP; MOV BP, SP do?
Where are function parameters typically located?

lessons.title: Strings & System Calls
lessons.theory: Strings are byte arrays ending with null (0). Use LOADB/STOREB for byte operations. System calls: SYS #1 prints R0 as integer, SYS #2 prints null-terminated string at address in R1, SYS #3 exits with code in R0. Always null-terminate strings for proper printing.

snippets.label: String Operations
snippets.source:
.DATA
str1: .STRING "Hello"
str2: .STRING " World"
buffer: .SPACE 20
.TEXT
; Copy str1 to buffer
MOV R0, str1
MOV R1, buffer
copy_loop:
LOADB R2, [R0]
STOREb [R1], R2
CMP R2, #0
JZ done
INC R0
INC R1
JMP copy_loop
done:
MOV R1, buffer
SYS #2
HALT

snippets.label: String Length & Print
snippets.source:
.DATA
msg: .STRING "Assembly!"
.TEXT
MOV R0, msg
MOV R1, #0
len_loop:
LOADB R2, [R0]
CMP R2, #0
JZ print_len
INC R1
INC R0
JMP len_loop
print_len:
MOV R0, R1
SYS #1
MOV R1, msg
SYS #2
SYS #3
HALT

quiz.q: What instruction reads a single byte?
Which SYS call prints a string?

lessons.title: Array Algorithms
lessons.theory: Array algorithms process elements systematically. Sum: iterate and accumulate. Max: compare each element with current maximum. Rotation: shift elements by K positions, wrapping around. Always check bounds to prevent memory corruption. Use temporary storage for complex operations.

snippets.label: Array Sum & Max
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9
len: .WORD 6
.TEXT
MOV R0, #0
LOAD R1, [array]
MOV R2, array
LOAD R3, [len]
loop:
LOAD R4, [R2]
ADD R0, R4
CMP R4, R1
JLE skip
MOV R1, R4
skip:
ADD R2, #4
DEC R3
JNZ loop
HALT

snippets.label: Array Rotate Right
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 1, 2, 3, 4
len: .WORD 4
k: .WORD 1
temp: .SPACE 16
.TEXT
; Copy to temp with rotation
MOV R0, array
MOV R1, temp
LOAD R2, [len]
LOAD R3, [k]
MOV R4, #0
copy_loop:
MOV R5, R4
ADD R5, R3
CMP R5, R2
JL no_wrap
SUB R5, R2
no_wrap:
MUL R5, #4
ADD R5, array
LOAD R6, [R5]
STORE [R1], R6
ADD R1, #4
INC R4
CMP R4, R2
JL copy_loop
HALT

quiz.q: To rotate array right by K, element at index i goes to?
What's the time complexity of finding array maximum?

lessons.title: Memory Safety & Bounds Checks
lessons.theory: Memory safety prevents crashes and security issues. Always validate array indices before access. Check string lengths before copying. Use bounds checking: if (index >= 0 && index < length). Initialize memory before use. Never access memory outside allocated regions.

snippets.label: Safe Array Access
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 10, 20, 30
len: .WORD 3
index: .WORD 5
.TEXT
LOAD R0, [index]
LOAD R1, [len]
CMP R0, #0
JL error
CMP R0, R1
JGE error
; Safe access
MUL R0, #4
ADD R0, array
LOAD R2, [R0]
JMP done
error:
MOV R2, #-1
done:
HALT

snippets.label: Safe String Copy
snippets.source:
.DATA
src: .STRING "Hello World"
dest: .SPACE 6
max_len: .WORD 5
.TEXT
MOV R0, src
MOV R1, dest
LOAD R2, [max_len]
MOV R3, #0
copy_loop:
CMP R3, R2
JGE truncate
LOADB R4, [R0]
CMP R4, #0
JZ null_term
STOREb [R1], R4
INC R0
INC R1
INC R3
JMP copy_loop
truncate:
null_term:
MOV R4, #0
STOREb [R1], R4
HALT

quiz.q: What should you check before accessing array[i]?
What happens if you access memory outside array bounds?

lessons.title: Bitwise Tricks
lessons.theory: Bitwise operations work on individual bits. AND masks bits (x & mask), OR sets bits (x | mask), XOR toggles bits (x ^ mask). Left shift (SHL) multiplies by 2^n, right shift (SHR) divides by 2^n. Common tricks: x & 1 checks odd/even, x & (x-1) clears lowest set bit.

snippets.label: Bit Manipulation
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #42
; Check if odd
MOV R1, R0
AND R1, #1
; Multiply by 8 using shift
MOV R2, R0
SHL R2, #3
; Clear lowest bit
MOV R3, R0
AND R3, #0xFE
; Set bit 2
MOV R4, R0
OR R4, #4
; Toggle bit 1
MOV R5, R0
XOR R5, #2
HALT

snippets.label: Power of 2 Check
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #16
; Check if power of 2
; (x & (x-1)) == 0 for powers of 2
MOV R1, R0
DEC R1
AND R1, R0
; R1 = 0 if R0 is power of 2
CMP R1, #0
JZ is_power
MOV R2, #0
JMP done
is_power:
MOV R2, #1
done:
HALT

quiz.q: What does x & 1 check?
Left shift by N positions multiplies by?

lessons.title: Debugger Workflows
lessons.theory: Effective debugging requires systematic approaches. Set breakpoints at function entries, loop starts, and before critical operations. Watch key variables and memory locations. Use step-over for function calls, step-into for detailed analysis. Watchpoints trigger when memory changes. Trace execution to understand program flow.

snippets.label: Debug Loop Algorithm
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 5, 2, 8, 1, 9
len: .WORD 5
.TEXT
; Find minimum - set breakpoint here
MOV R0, array
LOAD R1, [R0]
MOV R2, #1
loop:
; Watch R1 (current min), R2 (index)
CMP R2, [len]
JGE done
MOV R3, R2
MUL R3, #4
ADD R3, array
LOAD R4, [R3]
CMP R4, R1
JGE skip
MOV R1, R4
skip:
INC R2
JMP loop
done:
HALT

snippets.label: Debug Function Call
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #6
CALL factorial
; Set breakpoint here to check result
HALT

factorial:
; Watch SP, BP, R0 throughout
PUSH BP
MOV BP, SP
CMP R0, #1
JLE base_case
DEC R0
CALL factorial
INC R0
MUL R0, R0
JMP return
base_case:
MOV R0, #1
return:
MOV SP, BP
POP BP
RET

quiz.q: When should you set a breakpoint in a loop?
What's the best way to debug a recursive function?

lessons.title: Addressing Modes Deep Dive
lessons.theory: Advanced addressing modes enable efficient data structure access. Base+index [base+index*scale] for arrays, displacement [reg+offset] for structures, pre/post-increment for sequential access. Understanding addressing modes is crucial for performance and code density.

snippets.label: Structure Access
snippets.source:
.DATA
student: .WORD 12345, 85, 92, 78
; ID at +0, grade1 at +4, grade2 at +8, grade3 at +12
.TEXT
MOV R0, student
LOAD R1, [R0+0]
; Load ID
LOAD R2, [R0+4]
; Load grade1
LOAD R3, [R0+8]
; Load grade2
LOAD R4, [R0+12]
; Load grade3
HALT

snippets.label: 2D Array Access
snippets.source:
.DATA
matrix: .WORD 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
; 2x3 matrix: [[1,2,3], [4,5,6]]
.TEXT
; Access matrix[1][2] = 6
MOV R0, #1
; row
MOV R1, #2
; col
MOV R2, #3
; cols per row
MUL R0, R2
; row * cols
ADD R0, R1
; + col
MUL R0, #4
; * sizeof(WORD)
ADD R0, matrix
; + base
LOAD R3, [R0]
; R3 = 6
HALT

quiz.q: To access element [i][j] in a 2D array with W columns, the offset is?
What's the advantage of [base+index] addressing?

lessons.title: Flags Truth Table & Conditional Jumps
lessons.theory: CPU flags work together to indicate operation results. Signed comparisons use NF and OF (JL, JG), unsigned use CF (JB, JA). Zero flag (ZF) indicates equality. Understanding flag combinations enables complex conditional logic and efficient branching.

snippets.label: Signed vs Unsigned
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #0xFFFFFFFF
; -1 in signed, large positive in unsigned
MOV R1, #1
CMP R0, R1
; Compare -1 with 1
; For signed: -1 < 1, so NF=1, OF=0
; For unsigned: 0xFFFFFFFF > 1, so CF=0
JL signed_less
; Jump if signed less
MOV R2, #0
JMP check_unsigned
signed_less:
MOV R2, #1
check_unsigned:
CMP R0, R1
JB unsigned_less
; Jump if unsigned less
MOV R3, #0
JMP done
unsigned_less:
MOV R3, #1
done:
HALT

snippets.label: Flag Combinations
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
MOV R1, #5
; Test all comparisons
CMP R0, R1
; 10 - 5 = 5: ZF=0, NF=0, CF=0, OF=0
MOV R2, #0
JZ equal
JL less
JG greater
JMP done
equal:
MOV R2, #1
JMP done
less:
MOV R2, #2
JMP done
greater:
MOV R2, #3
done:
HALT

quiz.q: For signed comparison, which flags matter for JL (jump if less)?
What's the difference between JB and JL?
options: JB is unsigned, JL is signed
JB is signed, JL is unsigned

lessons.title: Stack Frames (SP/BP), CALL/RET
lessons.theory: Advanced stack frame management enables complex function calls with multiple parameters and local variables. Standard calling convention: caller pushes parameters right-to-left, callee sets up frame with PUSH BP; MOV BP,SP, allocates locals with SUB SP,#size, cleans up with MOV SP,BP; POP BP; RET.

snippets.label: Multi-Parameter Function
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #10
MOV R1, #20
MOV R2, #30
PUSH R2
; param3
PUSH R1
; param2
PUSH R0
; param1
CALL sum_three
ADD SP, #12
; Clean up parameters
HALT

sum_three:
PUSH BP
MOV BP, SP
; Parameters at BP+8, BP+12, BP+16
LOAD R0, [BP+8]
; param1
LOAD R1, [BP+12]
; param2
LOAD R2, [BP+16]
; param3
ADD R0, R1
ADD R0, R2
; Result in R0
MOV SP, BP
POP BP
RET

snippets.label: Function with Locals
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #5
PUSH R0
CALL square_with_temp
ADD SP, #4
HALT

square_with_temp:
PUSH BP
MOV BP, SP
SUB SP, #8
; Allocate 2 local variables
LOAD R0, [BP+8]
; Load parameter
STORE [BP-4], R0
; Store in local1
MUL R0, R0
; Square it
STORE [BP-8], R0
; Store in local2
LOAD R0, [BP-8]
; Load result
MOV SP, BP
; Deallocate locals
POP BP
RET

quiz.q: In standard calling convention, who cleans up parameters?
Where are local variables typically stored?

lessons.title: Strings + SYS calls (PRINT_INT/PRINT_STR)
lessons.theory: Advanced string operations combined with system calls enable rich program output. SYS #1 prints integers, SYS #2 prints null-terminated strings, SYS #3 exits with status code. String operations include length, copy, concatenation, comparison, and formatting.

snippets.label: String Concatenation
snippets.source:
.DATA
str1: .STRING "Hello "
str2: .STRING "World!"
buffer: .SPACE 20
.TEXT
; Copy str1 to buffer
MOV R0, str1
MOV R1, buffer
copy1:
LOADB R2, [R0]
STOREb [R1], R2
CMP R2, #0
JZ append
INC R0
INC R1
JMP copy1
append:
; Append str2 (overwrite null)
MOV R0, str2
copy2:
LOADB R2, [R0]
STOREb [R1], R2
CMP R2, #0
JZ done
INC R0
INC R1
JMP copy2
done:
MOV R1, buffer
SYS #2
SYS #3
HALT

snippets.label: Number to String
snippets.source:
.DATA
buffer: .SPACE 10
.TEXT
MOV R0, #1234
; Convert to string
MOV R1, buffer
ADD R1, #9
; Start from end
MOV R2, #0
STOREb [R1], R2
; Null terminator
DEC R1
convert:
MOV R3, R0
MOD R3, #10
; Get digit
ADD R3, #48
; Convert to ASCII
STOREb [R1], R3
DIV R0, #10
CMP R0, #0
JZ print
DEC R1
JMP convert
print:
INC R1
; Point to first digit
SYS #2
SYS #3
HALT

quiz.q: To convert digit 5 to ASCII character '5', you?
Which SYS call exits the program?

lessons.title: Bitwise Tricks (masking, shifting)
lessons.theory: Advanced bitwise operations enable efficient data packing and manipulation. Masks isolate bit fields: (value >> shift) & mask. Setting bits: value |= (1 << bit). Clearing bits: value &= ~(1 << bit). Toggling: value ^= (1 << bit). Bit fields pack multiple values in single word.

snippets.label: Bit Field Operations
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #0
; Pack RGB values (5-6-5 format)
MOV R1, #31
; Red (5 bits)
MOV R2, #63
; Green (6 bits)
MOV R3, #31
; Blue (5 bits)
; Pack: RRRRRGGGGGGBBBBB
SHL R1, #11
; Red to bits 15-11
SHL R2, #5
; Green to bits 10-5
; Blue already in bits 4-0
OR R0, R1
OR R0, R2
OR R0, R3
; Now unpack
MOV R4, R0
SHR R4, #11
AND R4, #31
; Extract red
MOV R5, R0
SHR R5, #5
AND R5, #63
; Extract green
MOV R6, R0
AND R6, #31
; Extract blue
HALT

snippets.label: Fast Multiplication/Division
snippets.source:
MOV R0, #100
; Multiply by 8 using shift
MOV R1, R0
SHL R1, #3
; R1 = R0 * 8
; Divide by 4 using shift
MOV R2, R0
SHR R2, #2
; R2 = R0 / 4
; Check if power of 2
MOV R3, #64
MOV R4, R3
DEC R4
AND R4, R3
; R4 = 0 if R3 is power of 2
; Fast modulo for power of 2
MOV R5, #123
MOV R6, #7
; R6 = 8-1, so mod 8
AND R5, R6
; R5 = 123 % 8
HALT

lessons.title: Debugger Workflows (breakpoints, watchpoints, trace)
lessons.theory: Advanced debugging combines multiple techniques for efficient problem solving. Breakpoints pause execution at specific points. Watchpoints trigger when memory changes. Execution traces show program flow. Conditional breakpoints reduce noise. Step-over vs step-into controls analysis depth.

snippets.label: Complex Algorithm Debug
snippets.source:
.DATA
array: .WORD 64, 34, 25, 12, 22
len: .WORD 5
.TEXT
; Bubble sort - set breakpoints strategically
LOAD R0, [len]
MOV R1, #0
; Outer loop - breakpoint here
outer_loop:
CMP R1, R0
JGE done
MOV R2, #0
; Inner loop - watch R2, R3, R4
inner_loop:
MOV R3, R0
SUB R3, R1
DEC R3
CMP R2, R3
JGE next_outer
; Compare adjacent elements - watchpoint on array
MOV R4, R2
MUL R4, #4
ADD R4, array
LOAD R5, [R4]
LOAD R6, [R4+4]
CMP R5, R6
JLE no_swap
; Swap - trace this section
STORE [R4], R6
STORE [R4+4], R5
no_swap:
INC R2
JMP inner_loop
next_outer:
INC R1
JMP outer_loop
done:
HALT

snippets.label: Memory Corruption Debug
snippets.source:
.DATA
buffer: .SPACE 20
canary: .WORD 0xDEADBEEF
.TEXT
; Set watchpoint on canary to detect overflow
MOV R0, buffer
MOV R1, #0
; Simulate potential overflow
fill_loop:
CMP R1, #25
; Intentionally go past buffer
JGE check_canary
MOV R2, #0x41
; 'A'
STOREb [R0], R2
INC R0
INC R1
JMP fill_loop
check_canary:
LOAD R3, [canary]
MOV R4, #0xDEADBEEF
CMP R3, R4
JE safe
MOV R5, #1
; Corruption detected
JMP done
safe:
MOV R5, #0
; Buffer safe
done:
HALT
